title: In Estonia, while we’re still married under a joint property regime, can I sell

history.content: In Estonia, while we’re still married under a joint property regime, can I sell “my half” of the marital assets or force a division?

Under Estonian law, while you are still married and under a joint property regime, you cannot sell "your half" of the marital assets or force a division of the joint property. According to Article 26, a spouse does not have the right to request the division of joint property during the jointness of property. Division can only occur after the termination of the joint property relationship. Therefore, you would need to wait until the marriage is dissolved or the joint property regime is terminated to pursue any division of assets.

Division
 (1) After termination of jointness of property the spouses shall divide joint property between themselves. A spouse may submit an application for the division of joint property to court already together with an action for divorce or annulment of marriage or together with an action for termination of jointness of property.
 (11) The composition of joint property shall be determined as of the termination of the proprietary relationship.

 (2) Until the division of joint property, the requirements for administration of joint property established in Subdivision 2 of this Subchapter shall apply to the possession, use and disposal of the joint property.

71
DIVISION OF CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) Co-owned property of spouses shall be divided if their marriage is terminated. During marriage, co-owned property may be divided by agreement or on the proposal of either of the spouses.
(2) The agreement referred to in the preceding paragraph shall also contain an agreement between the spouses on the amount of their co-owned property.
(3) If the marital property agreement whereby the spouses modify the legal property regime does not define the manner of division of co-owned property, such co-owned property shall be divided according to the legal property regime rules, unless the spouses agree otherwise. Division shall be carried out according to the status of property as at the date of effect of the marital property agreement.

24.  
Selection of proprietary relationship
Prospective spouses may, by agreement, select a proprietary relationship from among the types of proprietary relations set out in Subchapter 2 of this Chapter before the contraction of marriage by an application for marriage pursuant to the procedure prescribed in the Vital Statistics Registration Act. The abovementioned declaration of intention takes effect upon the contraction of marriage.
If the prospective spouses do not select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and do not enter into a marital property contract, the provisions regarding jointness of property shall apply to their proprietary relations as of the contraction of marriage. The provisions regarding jointness of property shall also apply if the spouses have not selected the type of proprietary relations by an agreement to apply Estonian law to the proprietary rights.
If spouses select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and, in addition, enter into a marital property contract, the marital property contract shall be applied to the proprietary relations between the spouses.

history.content: My spouse and I want to change our matrimonial property regime in Italy. What form does the agreement need, and when does it bind third parties?

To change your matrimonial property regime in Italy, the agreement must be concluded by an authentic instrument, as stipulated by Article 162 of the Italian Civil Code. This means that the agreement must be formalized in a specific legal format, typically requiring notarization to be valid and binding. 

Regarding the binding effect on third parties, the agreement becomes effective against them once it has been registered in the public records. This registration is crucial to ensure that third parties are aware of the changes in the matrimonial property regime and can rely on the information.

Please note that while this information is based on legal provisions, specific cases may vary, and it is advisable to consult a legal professional for personalized guidance.

history.content: In Estonia, if I’m entitled to a compulsory portion, how big is it and what do I actually receive?

In Estonia, if you are entitled to a compulsory portion, it is calculated as one-half of the value of the share of the estate that you would have received in the case of intestate succession, assuming all intestate successors accepted the succession. If the share you have been bequeathed is smaller than the compulsory portion, you can claim the difference from the co-successors. Additionally, if you receive a legacy that is less than your compulsory portion, you may claim the compulsory portion from the successors, provided you renounce the legacy. 

To formalize your claim, a notary will authenticate a certificate that details the recipient and the size of the compulsory portion as a legal share of the estate.
contexts:
ACT
105.  
Size of compulsory portion
A compulsory portion is one-half of the value of the share of an estate which a successor would have received in the case of intestate succession if all intestate successors would have accepted the succession. The persons who renounce a succession by a contract shall not be taken into account upon determining the size of a compulsory portion.
If a person entitled to claim a compulsory portion has been bequeathed a share of an estate which is smaller than a compulsory portion, he or she may claim the deficient share as a compulsory portion from the co-successors.
If one from several successors has the right to receive a compulsory portion, he or she may refuse to satisfy the claim of some other person entitled to compulsory portion to such extent that he or she would receive his or her compulsory portion. Other successors shall be liable for the deficit.
If a legacy is given to a person entitled to a compulsory portion, he or she has a claim for the compulsory portion only in case he or she renounces the legacy. If the value of a legacy is lower than a compulsory portion, the person may claim a compulsory portion from the successors to the extent which he or she received less as legacy than he or she would have received as a compulsory portion.

ACT
107.  
Encumbrances of compulsory portion
If the rights of a person nominated as a successor and entitled to compulsory portion are restricted by nominating a subsequent successor or an executor of the will, or if he or she is encumbered by a testamentary obligation, the restriction or encumbrance shall not be valid if the share of the estate bequeathed to him or her is less than one-half of the share of the estate belonging to him or her in intestacy.
If the bequeathed share of an estate is bigger, the person entitled to compulsory portion may claim the compulsory portion in case of renunciation of the share of the estate. The term for renunciation commences at the moment when the person entitled to compulsory portion becomes aware of the restriction or encumbrance.
The restriction of nomination of a person as a successor is equal to nomination of a person entitled to compulsory portion as a subsequent successor.

history.content: If inherited real estate can’t be divided conveniently among heirs, can the court order a public auction and split the proceeds?

Yes, if inherited real estate cannot be conveniently divided among heirs, the court can order a public auction of the property and split the proceeds among the heirs. This is supported by Article 719 of the Italian Civil Code, which allows for the sale of property by auction when coheirs agree on the necessity of the sale, particularly for the payment of debts and burdens of the estate.
contexts:
719 SALE OF PROPERTY FOR THE PAYMENT OF HEREDITARY DEBTS
If the coheirs entitled to more than half of the estate agree in the necessity of the sale for the payment of the debts and burdens of the estate, the movable property and, if necessary, those immovable property whose alienation would be less prejudicial to the interests of the sharers shall be sold by auction.
When the consent of all parties concurs, the sale might follow among the sharers only and without publicity, unless there is opposition from legatees or creditors.

Distribution of objects forming part of estate
In the distribution of objects forming part of an estate, the special needs and interests of each co-successor, the wishes of the majority of co-successors and the testamentary intention of the testator pursuant to the will or succession contract shall be considered.

history.content: I’m married under a community/joint property regime. Can I sell or gift my “share” of the marital property while still married, if we’re in Estonia vs. Slovenia?

In Estonia, under a community property regime, both spouses generally have equal rights to manage and dispose of community property. However, significant transactions such as selling or gifting a share of the marital property typically require the consent of both spouses. Therefore, you would need your spouse's agreement to sell or gift your share of the marital property.

In Slovenia, similar principles apply under a community property regime. You cannot unilaterally sell or gift your share of the marital property without your spouse's consent, as both spouses have equal rights to the community property.

In summary, in both Estonia and Slovenia, you cannot sell or gift your share of the marital property without the consent of your spouse while still married.
contexts:
ARTICLE 179 
PERSONAL PROPERTY
They do not constitute objects of community and are personal property of the spouse:
(a) property owned by the spouse before the marriage or had a right in rem to enjoy;
(b) property acquired after marriage by way of gift or inheritance, where it is not specified in the gift deed or will that it is to be allocated to the community;
(c) property for the strictly personal use of each spouse and its accessories;
(d) property used in the exercise of the spouse's profession, except property used for the purpose of running a business forming part of the community;
(e) property obtained by way of damages as well as the pension relating to the partial or total loss of the capacity to work;
(f) goods acquired with the price of the transfer of the personal property listed above or by exchange thereof, provided that this is expressly stated at the time of purchase.
The acquisition of real property, or of movable property listed in Article 2683, made after the marriage, shall be excluded from community of property, within the meaning of points (c), (d) and (f) of the preceding paragraph, where such exclusion is apparent from the deed of acquisition if the other spouse was also a party to it.


24.  
Selection of proprietary relationship
Prospective spouses may, by agreement, select a proprietary relationship from among the types of proprietary relations set out in Subchapter 2 of this Chapter before the contraction of marriage by an application for marriage pursuant to the procedure prescribed in the Vital Statistics Registration Act. The abovementioned declaration of intention takes effect upon the contraction of marriage.
If the prospective spouses do not select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and do not enter into a marital property contract, the provisions regarding jointness of property shall apply to their proprietary relations as of the contraction of marriage. The provisions regarding jointness of property shall also apply if the spouses have not selected the type of proprietary relations by an agreement to apply Estonian law to the proprietary rights.
If spouses select a proprietary relationship by an application for marriage and, in addition, enter into a marital property contract, the marital property contract shall be applied to the proprietary relations between the spouses.


ARTICLE 210
CONVENTIONAL CHANGES TO LEGAL COMMUNITY OF PROPERTY
The spouses may, by means of an agreement concluded in accordance with Article 162, i.e. by public instrument or by declaration in the marriage certificate, modify the rules governing community of property, provided that the agreements are not contrary to the provisions of Article 161, i.e. the spouses can not stipulate in a general manner that their property relationships shall be governed in whole or in part by laws to which they are not subject or by custom.
The property referred to in points (c), (d) and (e) of Article 179, i.e. property for the strictly personal use of each spouse and its accessories, property used in the exercise of the spouse's profession, except for property used to run a business forming part of the community, and property obtained by way of compensation for damage as well as the pension relating to the partial or total loss of the capacity to work cannot be included in the contractual community.
The rules of legal community of property regarding the administration of community property and the equality of shares limited to the property that would be the subject of legal community of property cannot be derogated from.


211.  
Marital property right
 (1) In the case of marriages contracted before entry into force of this Act, the provisions of this Act regarding jointness of property apply to the proprietary relations between spouses as of entry into force of this Act unless otherwise provided for in a marital property contract entered into before entry into force of this Act.
(2) In the proprietary relationship of jointness of property the procedure for administration of separate property provided for in § 271 of this Act applies to the property acquired after entry into force of § 271


ARTICLE 215 
SEPARATION OF PROPERTY
The spouses may agree that each of them shall retain sole ownership of the property acquired during the marriage.


26.
Principle of unity of joint property
A spouse cannot dispose of his or her share in joint property or in a single object included in joint property. A spouse does not have the right to request the division of joint property during the jointness of property.
A claim owned by spouses jointly may be set off only against a claim the satisfaction of which out of the joint property is prescribed by law or by an agreement.


25 
Joint property
In the case of jointness of property, the objects and other proprietary rights of the spouses acquired during the jointness of property shall transfer into the joint ownership of the spouses (hereinafter joint property).


28.  
Principles of joint administration of joint property
 (1) Unless otherwise agreed, spouses shall jointly exercise the rights and perform the obligations relating to joint property. Spouses have the right to possess jointly the objects forming part of their joint property.
 (2) Spouses may transfer the right to administer joint property to one of the spouses by a marital property contract.
 (3) Spouses shall administer joint property in the interests of matrimonial cohabitation and regular management of the property. They shall inform each other of the acts of administration of property and of the financial status.
 (4) A spouse may require conclusion of transactions necessary for correction of an entry concerning an object included in the joint property to be entered in the register.


90
REGISTER OF MARITAL PROPERTY AGREEMENTS
(1) The register of marital property agreements is an electronic database maintained by the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia.
(2) When future spouses who have signed a marital property agreement marry, they shall send the extract from the register of births, marriages and deaths (civil register) containing data on the marriage to the notary that drew up the marital property agreement.
(3) A notary who draws up a marital property agreement or an amendment to a marital property agreement shall send to the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia a request to enter such agreement in the register of marital property agreements within eight days of the date of receipt of the extract from the civil register containing data on marriage or within eight days from the conclusion or amendment of the marital property agreement concluded or amended after the conclusion of marriage.  Where the spouses conclude or amend a marital property agreement which does not come into effect on the day of conclusion of marriage or on the day of conclusion or amendment of the marital property agreement, the notary shall send to the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia a request to enter such agreement in the register of marital property agreements within eight days of the date of effect of the marital property agreement.
(4) Where spouses conclude marriage abroad, they shall send to the notary the extract from the civil register containing data on the marriage, unless otherwise provided by an international treaty. The notary shall send to the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia a request for entry of the agreement in the register of marital property agreements within eight days of the date of receipt of the extract.
(5) A notary who draws up a marital property agreement or an amendment to a marital property agreement shall indicate in the request for entry in the register of marital property agreements the data referred to in paragraph two of Article 93 of this Code that are available to them.
(6) A request for entry of termination of validity of a marital property agreement shall be sent to the notary that drew up the agreement of the spouses who had concluded the marital property agreement or by their legal successors. The notary shall send to the Chamber of Notaries of Slovenia a request for entry of termination of marital property agreement complete with termination date, within eight days of the date of receipt of the request.
 
FAMILY 

68
SPOUSES' SHARES IN CO-OWNED PROPERTY
(1) Co-owned property of spouses shall belong jointly to both spouses. Shares belonging to each spouse shall not be specified in the co-owned property.
(2) A spouse may not dispose of their unspecified share of co-owned property by legal transactions inter vivos, and in particular, they may not expropriate or encumber it.
(3) Items that are part of co-owned property shall be jointly owned by the spouses.

history.content: My siblings and I inherited an apartment in Italy, but it can’t be conveniently divided. What does the civil code say should happen, and do courts actually proceed with an auction sale?

In Italy, when siblings inherit real estate that cannot be conveniently divided, the civil code provides for the possibility of selling the property through a public auction. Courts have indeed proceeded with auction sales in similar cases. For instance, in one case, the court ordered the dissolution of a community of inherited properties and remitted the case to a notary public for the sale of the properties at auction, with the proceeds to be distributed among the heirs. This aligns with the legal principles that govern the division of inheritance assets when physical division is impractical. Therefore, it is likely that your situation could lead to a similar outcome, where the court may order an auction sale of the apartment.

history.content: In Slovenia, when can a spouse request judicial separation of assets ? What are the legal triggers, and what can a court practically order in a real dispute?

In Slovenia, a spouse can request judicial separation of assets during divorce proceedings or when there is a significant change in circumstances that affects the management of joint property. Legal triggers for such a request may include disputes over asset ownership, financial contributions, or the need to protect one spouse's interests due to the other spouse's actions.

In practical terms, a court can order the division of assets, which may include real estate, bank accounts, and shares in companies. For instance, courts have confirmed equal division of assets, as seen in cases where properties and financial contributions were assessed. Courts may also order one spouse to pay a specific amount to the other, along with interest, and can address procedural issues and costs related to the proceedings.

These insights are supported by recent legal cases in Slovenia, which illustrate the court's approach to asset division and the factors considered in determining financial contributions and ownership rights.

ARTICLE 193 
JUDICIAL SEPARATION OF ASSETS
Judicial separation of property may be pronounced in the event of interdiction or incapacitation of one of the spouses or maladministration of the community.
It may also be pronounced when the disorder of the affairs of one of the spouses or the conduct of one of the spouses in the administration of property endangers the interests of the other or of the community or the family, or when one of the spouses does not contribute to the latter's needs in proportion to his or her substance and capacity for work.
Separation may be requested by one of the spouses or his or her legal representative.
The judgment pronouncing the separation run from the day on which the application was made and shall have the effect of establishing the separation of property regime regulated in Section V of this Chapter, without prejudice to the rights of third parties.
The judgment is noted in the margin of the marriage certificate and on the original of the marriage agreements.

history.content: In civil law, what’s the difference between a void contract and a voidable contract, and what are the consequences?

In Italian civil law, the distinction between a void contract and a voidable contract is significant, though the context of inheritance primarily deals with the validity of wills and testamentary dispositions rather than contracts in general.

1. **Void Contract**: A void contract is one that is null from the outset and has no legal effect. For example, dispositions in favor of a notary or witnesses involved in a will are considered null and void (Article 597). Similarly, a will lacking proper form, such as a signature, is also null (Article 606).

2. **Voidable Contract**: A voidable contract, on the other hand, is valid until one party chooses to void it. This type of contract remains enforceable unless the party with the right to void it decides to do so. The context of voidable contracts is less explicitly covered in the retrieved documents, but generally, they would allow for certain remedies or confirmations unless acted upon.

**Consequences**:
- For void contracts, there are no legal obligations or rights arising from them, and they cannot be enforced by either party.
- For voidable contracts, the party with the right to void the contract can choose to affirm it, which would allow it to remain in effect.

In summary, while the documents primarily address the validity of wills and testamentary dispositions, the general principles of void and voidable contracts apply similarly in broader civil law contexts.
contexts:
597 INCAPACITY OF NOTARY, WITNESSES AND INTERPRETER.
Dispositions in favor of the notary or other official who received the public will, or in favor of any of the witnesses or interpreter who intervened in the will, are null and void.

 
598 INCAPACITY OF THE PERSON WHO WROTE OR RECEIVED THE SECRET WILL.
Dispositions in favor of the person who wrote the secret will are null and void, unless they are approved by the testator himself or in the act of delivery. Provisions in favor of the notary to whom the secret will was delivered in an unsealed envelope are also null and void.


105
INVALIDITY OF A CONTRACT ON THE CONTENTS OF A WILL
A contract by which a person obliges him- or herself to determine something in his or her will, or to not determine something, or to revoke a provision in his or her will, or to not revoke a provision, shall be invalid.
 

520 CONDITIONAL, TERM OR PARTIAL WAIVER
A waiver made under condition or term or only in part is void.
 

606 NULLITY OF WILL FOR LACK OF FORM
A will is null and void when there is a lack of autograph or signature in the case of a holographic will, or a lack of writing by the notary of the declarations of the testator or a signature of either, in the case of a will by deed of notary.
For any other defect of form, the will may be annulled at the instance of any person having an interest therein. The action for annulment prescribes in five years from the day of execution of the testamentary provisions 


104
INVALIDITY OF A CONTRACT OF EXPECTED INHERITANCE OR LEGACY
(1) A contract in which a person alienates an expected inheritance shall be invalid, as shall any contract of inheritance from another person who is still alive.
(2) Equally, a contract of a legacy or another benefit that a party to a contract expects from an inheritance that has not yet occurred shall be invalid.
 

590 CONFIRMATION AND VOLUNTARY EXECUTION OF VOID TESTAMENTARY DISPOSITIONS
The nullity of testamentary disposition, from whatever cause it may depend, cannot be invoked by one who, knowing the cause of the nullity, has, after the death of the testator, confirmed the disposition or voluntarily executed it.
 

619 NULLITY
Wills provided for in this section shall be null when they lack the annotation in writing of the declaration of the testator or the signature of the person authorized to receive it or of the testator.
For other defects in form, the provisions of the second paragraph of ART606 shall be observed.


768-TER FORM
Under penalty of nullity, the contract must be concluded by public deed.


103
INVALIDITY OF AN INHERITANCE CONTRACT
A contract in which a person leaves his or her estate or a portion of the estate to the other party or another person shall be invalid.

history.content: In civil law, what must be proven to establish non-contractual (tort) liability for negligence?

In Italian civil law regarding inheritance, to establish non-contractual (tort) liability for negligence, it must be proven that the heir acted with gross negligence in the administration of the estate. According to Article 491, an heir with the benefit of inventory is not liable for the administration of the estate except in cases of gross negligence. This means that a standard of care must be demonstrated, and any failure to meet this standard that results in damage could lead to liability. 

The context provided does not specifically address general principles of tort liability outside of inheritance cases, but it emphasizes the importance of negligence in the administration of an estate.

in this legal case the tartu county court ruled in favor of the defendant after a 9month process the defendant has been ordered to pay procedural costs of €1824 the courts final resolution known as court dec replaces previous declarations of intent according to the civil code act the defendants are jointly responsible for the costs and must pay them within a specified deadline failure to do so may result in enforcement measures the defendants had the opportunity to submit a written response but failed to do so they can file an appeal against the default judgment within 30 days if they have a valid reason the appeal must be submitted to the tartu county court additionally an echo can be submitted within 30 days of becoming aware of the default judgment including necessary documents for the civil case if the claimant wishes to appeal it must be done within 30 days of receiving the decision and submitted to the tartu district court the courts judgment is based on the law succession act and the law property act which outline restrictions on asset distribution the procedural costs are determined based on the code civil procedure including state fees and legal aid costs in this case the defendant is required to pay a total of €2526 in state fees and justified expenses the claimants legal aid costs of nine hours totaling €1170 including vat are considered necessary and justified the court has ordered the defendant to pay the procedural costs late in accordance with the civil code

this legal text describes the resolution of a court case involving the division of a property located in torano castello the property includes a craft workshop and a civil dwelling the court assigned ownership shares to the parties involved including heirs and a spouse the defendants were ordered to pay the costs of the proceedings the court conducted a preliminary investigation to determine the value of the property and rental income an expert prepared a report detailing the propertys value and the shares due to each party the court also addressed the payment of rents and management of the deceaseds bank account it found that the heirs had not properly accounted for the rents and ordered them to pay the remaining balance the court ordered the distribution of shares and the allocation of shares to a noninterestbearing account the defendants were instructed to pay the remaining balance and the costs of the proceedings overall this legal document outlines the progress of the case including the division of assets and the financial responsibilities of the parties involved

this legal case involved a dispute between pp gp their brother pap and sisterinlaw ls regarding the inheritance of an apartment in albenga the plaintiffs claimed that they were harmed and demanded a declaration of harmfulness division of the property restitution of money and valuables and dissolution of the community inheritance the defendants argued against the claims and requested the plaintiffs to pay for inheritance expenses after several years of proceedings the court in savona made a final ruling the court rejected some claims found some to be unfounded and granted others it determined the value of the real estate properties and the rightful share of the parties involved the court also identified additional properties and assigned them to the heirs costs of the proceedings were offset and one party was ordered to pay certain costs the court referred to specific articles of the civil code in making its decision the judgment is provisionally enforceable

In civil law, what must be proven to establish non-contractual (tort) liability for negligence?
In Estonia, if spouses have a claim owned jointly (e.g., a receivable), can it be set off during the property-division dispute? How does a court net amounts in practice?

In Estonia, during a property-division dispute in divorce cases, joint claims (such as receivables) can indeed be set off. The court typically assesses the value of joint assets and liabilities, determining how they should be divided. In practice, the court will net amounts by evaluating the contributions of each party to the joint property and any claims made, ensuring that the division reflects the equitable interests of both spouses. The court's decisions are guided by the family law act and property act, as seen in recent rulings where joint assets were divided, and compensation was awarded based on the evidence presented.
contexts: this is a summary of a legal case in estonia that lasted for 3 years and 9 months the harju county court made a final decision on november 16 2020 the case revolves around a civil dispute between two parties identified as v and n regarding the division of joint property the plaintiff v filed a lawsuit seeking a division of the joint property and certain declarations the defendant n filed a counterclaim seeking a division of the joint property and a monetary compensation of 3500 euros the court ruled that the joint property should be divided with certain properties awarded to each party the court also ordered the removal of mortgages and prohibition notices from the properties certain movable property and money were left in the possession of each party the court declared the enforcement case inadmissible and canceled certain measures related to the enforcement proceedings each party is responsible for their own procedural costs the text provides a detailed account of the legal arguments and justifications for the courts decision the specific code articles mentioned in the original text are not provided

in this legal case in estonia the harju county court made a final decision after a 3year and 11month process the court ruled that one party is responsible for covering the procedural costs although the specific amount was not mentioned the court partially dismissed one partys claim and partially satisfied the other partys counterclaim the court divided the joint assets between the parties leaving certain shares and awarding compensation to each party the court rejected certain claims for the distribution of compensation and expenses incurred by the joint assets the court also stated that the procedural costs would be borne by the parties the court canceled a previous order and prohibited the disposal of certain property both parties have the option to appeal the courts decision within 30 days the court based its decision on the family law act and the property act the court considered whether certain assets should be recognized as joint or separate and whether certain expenses should be included in the joint assets the court also examined transfers made by one party to the other during the marriage to determine if they should be considered contributions to the joint assets the court found evidence to support some claims but dismissed others the court determined the value of certain assets based on the evidence provided the court also addressed the division of joint assets and ordered compensation to be paid to one party procedural costs were assigned to one party but the court partially exempted them from paying certain costs state legal aid was assigned to one party and the court ruled on the payment of procedural costs the summary does not provide specific details about the parties involved or the code articles referenced in the original text

claimant financial compensation for the expenses incurred in acquiring repairing and maintaining the apartment the court also orders the defendant to give consent for a change in ownership entry in by a judge named v j

in this legal case one party is responsible for covering the procedural costs although the exact amount was not specified the plaintiff is requesting the division of joint property located in tallinn they want to sell the property through a public auction and divide the proceeds equally between them and the defendant alternatively the plaintiff is willing to leave the property solely to the defendant if the defendant pays half of the propertys value in cash the defendant contests the value of the property and requests an expert to determine its value they also argue that the joint ownership should be terminated and that the defendant should compensate the plaintiff for their share of the money used for the joint property the court will make a decision based on the evidence presented by both parties and the relevant laws the defendant provides evidence to prove that they used their separate property to benefit the joint property they also want to divide additional common property mentioned in the lawsuit the defendant has submitted a written testimony regarding a sum of money given to them in 1997 the court finds this evidence convincing and orders the defendant to compensate the plaintiff for the value of their separate property the court also needs to determine how to divide the common property the court decides that it is fair for the defendant to compensate divided equally between the parties each party is ordered to bear their own procedural costs except for the experts cost in determining the market value of the property which the plaintiff is ordered account the division of common property

in this legal case in estonia the tartu county court made a final decision after 7 months the details of the case are not mentioned but one party will be responsible for covering the procedural costs the courts decision referred to as court dec has been delivered to the parties involved and entered into force if someone wants to appeal the decision they have 30 days to do so the case involves a divorce between two parties with joint assets including a property valued at 64000 euros the claimant wants to sell the property and divide the proceeds equally while the defendant believes it should be left for public use the court grants the divorce and decides to divide the joint assets as requested by the claimant the procedural costs of the divorce will be borne by both parties while the costs related to the division of joint assets will be borne by the defendant the defendant must pay a portion of the claimants procedural costs based on the code civil procedure section 190 paragraph 3 the defendant has 30 days to pay the specified amount

this legal case involves multiple parties including the republic of estonia the european union eu vl division common property and ü aa the eu filed a lawsuit against vl division common property requesting a change in the owners entry in the land register vl partially satisfied the eus counterclaim which also involved a change in the owners entry in the land register ü aa filed a lawsuit against the eu and vl claiming 54000 euros in arrears the court ruled that the procedural costs would be covered by one party but the exact amount was not specified the court also made decisions regarding the division of joint property including the sale of a real estate property and an apartment the court rejected the defendants claim to divide a car acquired during the marriage the court stated that the procedural costs would be borne by the parties involved the court also mentioned the possibility of appealing the decision within 30 days procedural aid may be granted to cover the costs of the proceedings if certain requirements are met the divorce division of joint property proceedings began in november 2019 and is still ongoing the court has made various decisions and judgments throughout the case considering the applicable laws and evidence presented by the parties the court has also addressed the validity of a partnership agreement and the contributions made by the partners the court has determined the division of assets and the compensation owed to the parties the court has also resolved disputes over the ownership of a vehicle the court has ordered the parties to bear their own procedural costs and the exact amount will be determined separately

in a legal case in estonia the pärnu county court ruled that the defendant is responsible for half of the claimants procedural costs the total cost awarded to the claimant was €483 the case involved two parties referred to as tp and ta who were demanding the division of a common property the court decided to satisfy the claim and terminate the property association the property will be sold at a public auction and the profit will be divided equally between tp and ta the court also explained the requirements for procedural assistance and the deadline for filing a complaint the original text refers to specific articles of the legal code the case started in 2022 and was transferred to the pärnu county court the defendant objected to the lawsuit and claimed the right to continue living in the apartment with their children the court scheduled a preliminary hearing for may 10 2022 in june 2022 the defendant failed to attend a court hearing so the claimant requested a default judgment the court accepted the claimants statements and dismissed the claim the court determined that the claimant and defendant should each bear half of the procedural costs the defendant objected to the amount but the court found it justified the decision on procedural costs can be appealed

in this legal case the tallinn district court made a decision regarding a claim for compensation and the division of joint assets between two parties referred to as x and y the court ruled that x is entitled to compensation of 1773451 euros and ordered the division of joint assets including a car shares and funds in bank accounts the court also determined that one party is responsible for covering the procedural costs but the exact amount was not specified x appealed the decision and the court granted the appeal in part the court explained the burden of proof in a civil case stating that the party relying on an obligation to compensate must prove the circumstances underlying their claim the court found that the defendants statements were contradictory and lacked evidence the court also found that the defendant wrongly reduced the joint assets by making transfers and withdrawing money and ordered them to compensate x the court concluded that the procedural costs should be shared by both parties the decision of the court is subject to further appeal to the supreme court

in this legal case the viru county court made a final decision after 9 months the case involves kr o and r who acquired joint assets during their marriage one of the assets is a property owned solely by r the court ordered r to change the owners entry in the land register and the partners entry in the business register to reflect rs sole ownership the procedural costs will be borne by the parties involved with the republic of estonia covering the costs of krs representative the claimant requested the termination of community assets and the default judgment is immediately enforceable if the claimant wants to appeal they have 30 days to do so the defendant has the right to respond within 30 days and must pay a state fee the court will determine the distribution of procedural costs and the person who requested the determination will be responsible for paying them the court found the claim legally justified and ordered the necessary changes in the registry the defendant is responsible for the procedural costs in a previous civil case kr was granted legal aid without the obligation to pay costs so the republic of estonia will cover the costs of the representative in another ruling the court partially granted krs request for procedural assistance and determined the financial responsibilities of each party

in this legal case a marriage between two parties was concluded in 2011 and they were divorced in 2022 they have joint assets including a property that is mortgaged the claimant wants to divide the property either through a public auction or by transferring it to the defendant with compensation the defendant agrees to sell the property through a public auction but also wants to acquire it through a counterclaim the court determines that the joint ownership should be terminated and the property should be sold through a public auction the parties are advised to reach a compromise the court also determines that the defendant should bear the procedural costs the claimant is awarded legal aid costs for the duration of the court hearing which were considered reasonable the total time spent on the hearing was 7 hours and 45 minutes additionally the defendant is ordered to compensate the claimants legal fees in the amount of 50 euros the judgment was partially annulled by the tallinn district court in 2023 a decision was made in a legal case involving two parties but the specific details are not provided
